div2.head: Warmup
div2.u: road shows, as he says.
Well, we haven't heard from the agent, the circuit. Right now there are none planned.
Just a little bit there. If you can lean in, Mr. Faulkner, without hurting it.
This is to remind us of our names. Wait a minute. I haven't got Blotner down there.
Yeah, you have.
But not—not—
No.
Why don't you just turn it around?
Just write his name on a piece of paper and pin it to him.
Like they do at conventions.
Preferably on the inside.
'Cause every now and then one of us just goes blind as far as the words are concerned—I mean names are concerned. Have you ever forgotten your own name, Joe?
No, but I've heard another announcer do it.
You did?
He said, "And your announcer has been"—. He just turned on the record.
Mr. Faulkner, do you think you will be sitting forward like that most of the time?
I can sit wherever you want me to.
Well,that—that'll be fine. Just about like that. I think Mr. Hench has a slightly louder voice and so it should balance it out.
Does he want to try us out?
Yes, sir. In just a second.
Alright. Well, this is cheating, in a way, to do these two fifteen minuteses and then to say that "Last week"—it's going to be awful hard—
You just lie one thing after another, don't you? A terrible liar.
Who, me?
Mmhmm.
Well, how is this—how does this sound? Is that alright? And Mr. Faulkner you could say, "Eeny meeny miney mo" or anything else.
If I know it, I will. You mean the rest of it or just "eeny meeny miney mo"?
just testing your voice.
All right.

div2.head: Blend Words
div2.u: Is that all right now? Can anyone tell me where these wonderful blend words in "Spotted Horses" are? "Sward" is one of them I remember. Can you hear me all right?
I haven't read "Spotted Horses" in a year, so I won't be able to tell you about that one.
I'm not sure I know where they are, Steve.
Did you make up that word "sward" or is that something you've heard?
No, no, that's the way they pronounce it.
Joe, Joe.
One, two, three, four, five. How's that? Does that—is that alright? A little more volume? Do you need some more gain?
Down a little.
One two, three, four, five. How's that? Okay?
That's all right."
What'd you say, game?
Gain, gain.
Oh, gain.
The engineer rides the gain. He picks it up or cuts it down.
Oh.
The opening is already on the tape, so any time you gentlemen feel ready.
Are you going to set the clock for us?
It is set, and we'll just start it. we'll give you twelve and a half minutes, sir, for the first show.
He's got some signals he doesn't understand. Oh, yes.
No rattling of elbows, then.
No rattling of elbows then. Let's not pound the table for once, shall we? I pounded the table once, and Steve pounded the table once in excitement.
It hasn't been done since.
I mustn't say "uh-huh".
Yesterday I opened that door, and it sounded like a pistol shot when it hit the wall in that basement.
It did.
jumped.
They ought to do something about ventilating that room. It was awfully hot in there.
It was getting pretty stuffy.
Blowers weren't on, were they?
I don't know.
It's supposed to be air conditioning with blowers, but I don't think they were on.
Mr. Stephenson, can I have a match, sir?
Sure.
Thank you.
Well, do you have—
Would you like to light it, Mr. Faulkner?
No, thank you, sir. I'm just about smoked out.
Do you have a lot of eloquent, impromptu comments there, Atch? Typed out?
I got my—my stuff. I—

div2.head: Introduction
div2.u: Today as our special guest we have with us the American novelist William Faulkner, author-in-residence at the University of Virginia this semester. We are indeed fortunate to have him with us. Also around our table today are our regular panel members Mr. Edward Stephenson and Mr. Robert Davis. As—and, as another special panel member today, we have Mr. Joseph Blotner, of the English Department. And our subject today is Mr. Faulkner's dialect. And I suppose we might as well lay on the table one plain fact, one simple fact at first, that it is Mississippi dialect. Isn't it, Mr. Faulkner?
As far as I know. I wouldn't limit it to Mississippi, though. I think I've heard this same dialect in Arkansas, Louisiana, Alabama. And I imagine, in time, I'll hear it here in Virginia.

div2.head: Mississippi v Southern Dialect
div2.u: Would you hear the same words, all the same vocabulary?
I wouldn't be surprised. I probably would.
Do you think so, Mr. Stephenson?
Well, I—

Well, the southern dialect—of course, I'm a native of Georgia, and I read many things in Mr. Faulkner's writings that are familiar to me. I run across some things that are not. I expect there might be some small differences.
Oh, yes, there would be small differences.
But it is a southern dialect.

div2.head: Types of Dialect
div2.u: By the way, Mr. Faulkner, how many different types of dialect do you try to distinguish? Now I notice, of course, the difference between the speech of the Negroes and the poor white trash. Are there any other distinctions that you try to make?

I would say there are three. The—the dialect, the diction, of the educated, semi-metropolitan white southerner, the dialect of the—of the hill, backwoods southerner, and the dialect of the Negro—four, the dialect of the Negro who has been influenced by the northern cities, who has been to Chicago and Detroit.
Four different dialects?
Four.

div2.head: Dialect and Status
div2.u: Do you find that your characters change their dialect as they improve in financial status?
Not always. Sometimes. The ones that are—that take up snobbery easily, yes, they will change their dialect, and young people have an aptitude for changing their dialect, like a chameleon does.

div2.head: Suption
div2.u: By the way, a friend of yours asked me to ask you a question today. He said that Flem Snopes doesn't smoke, but he'll chew a little tobacco till all the "suption" is out of it. He wanted me to ask you if you coined that word "suption."
No, no. Did you ever hear of that in Georgia, Mr. Stephenson?
No, I'm not familiar with that.
Well, it means nourishment. Now I don't know that I—
It doesn't mean juice?
Well, nourishment. There's suption in meat, in bread, it's—I think it's more nourishment than juice.
The goodness. We'd—I think we'd say he got the goodness out of it.
Goodness, yes, that's right.
Have you heard that in Alabama, Mr. Davis?
Suption? I don't think I've heard of suption but—
Maybe it's a Mississippi word.
When chewing gum is no longer sweet, the suption is gone.
Mmhmm.

div2.head: Pussel-gutted
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, I had—have down here on a list several words that I would like to ask you about. It's—one is the word "pussel-gutted." You spoke about Jewel calling his horse "pussel-gutted," and that was in mock affection. And then in another place Peabody—this is in, by the way, in As I Lay Dying—Peabody has "pussel-gutted" himself eating cold greens. I suppose that means make yourself flabby.
Bloated, yes.
That's a Georgia term. I know that term.
Is there a plant that you're—that is behind that figure of speech, pussel?
No.
There's a plant in Virginia called pussley, and I thought maybe it was the same thing. It's a hideous plant, an ugly plant. It gets full of water.
It could derive from that. I don't know. I've heard it all my life. It means someone that is bloated, that has a tremendous belly that he shouldn't have.

div2.head: Kernal v Cunnel
div2.u: May I come back for a moment to this distinction between the speech of the Negroes and of the—of what used to be called the poor white trash. In your short story "Wash," Mr. Faulkner, when Wash is talking about Colonel Sutpen, he call—you spell it K-E-R-N-E-L, when the Negroes are talking you spell it C-U-N-N-E-L. Is that supposed to be "Kernal' that Wash says, and "Cunnel" that the Negroes say. In other words, Negroes drop the "r."
That's correct.
That's the idea.
That's correct. And the—what we call the redneck white man has a hard "r."
He has the—
He says "fur" for far. He says "far" for fire.
Yes.
The Negro don't have the hard "r."

I assumed that that was the purpose of that. Now if Colonel Sutpen or one of his—upper class characters was speaking, then you just use the conventional spelling, which really would be rather like Wash's pronunciation, though not as hard on "r"'s.
That's right, it's between—
But the—between Wash and the Negroes, "Kernal" versus "Cunnel."
Yes.

div2.head: Peakling
div2.u: May I ask you about another word that I noticed, and that's the word "peakling." You said about Jewel, or rather in connection with Jewel it was said, "I told them that's why ma always whipped him and petted him more. Because he was "peakling" around the house.
That's probably a—a corruption or contraction between "puny" and "weakly." Just like the contraction or corruption between "mist" and "drizzle" becomes "mizzle."

div2.head: Ay for Yes
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, I noticed that Vernon and Uncle Billy, in As I Lay Dying, often say "ay" for "yes." I wondered if that was—if that was common or whether it was just characteristic of the older generation?
That is common among the older people whose ancestry was Scottish.
Oh, yes, sir.

They came to the mountains of North Carolina, then they came to the mountains of Virginia, then they came to the hills of Mississippi, and they kept their old ways. They would say to "red up" a room, just as you hear in Scotland—means to—to clean a room, to make the beds, sweep.

div2.head: Beholden
div2.u: Is the same thing true about "beholden"? I'm "beholden" to you.
Now would that be Scottish or is that Old English?
Well, I suppose it's English and Scottish.
Well, yes. That's right.
"Red" is certainly Scottish. You're right there.

div2.head: Spelling Dialect
div2.u: I'd like to make a point about the importance of knowing the author's speech in interpreting his dialect spellings. Now Thomas Nelson Page, for instance, when he wants to represent an Old Virginia Negro who says "cawn't," will spell that sometimes C-A-R-N-T. And I noticed you've done the same thing in "Wash." When the old Negro woman is talking to Colonel Sutpen, she says "Yes, mawster," and you spell it M-A-R-S-T-E-R. Now we should interpret that "mawster" rather than "master", but it isn't "marster," is it?
No.
It's "moster." And the "ar" spelling then, since we know that you are from a part of the country—and you yourself drop the "r" after a vowel, then the "ar" can be a symbol for the sound "aw."

div2.head: Winder
div2.u: I suppose, Mr. Faulkner, that'd be the same thing as when Dilsey says, "winda," and you spell it W-I-N-D-E-R. That she says "winda," rather than "winder."
That's right. There's no "r."
But now the backwoodsman would say "winder."
That's right.
Wouldn't he?
"Winder."
"Winder."
And then you'd have a problem because you'd have to spell it the same way if you wanted to represent it in dialect, wouldn't you? That'd be a problem for the author to worry about there.
I should say, being a Mississippian, I would probably put two r's on it.

That's what Page does, by the way—no not Page, but James Russell Lowell in his "Bigelow Papers" when he wants to represent—in certain parts of New England where they have a very hard "r," he puts two "r"'s. That's the same thing he does.

div2.head: Aguer
div2.u: Is that—is it the same way with that disease that I saw somewhere? A-G-U-E-R. An "aga"? Is that right? "Aga."
Yes, that's right.

div2.head: Ara v Ary
div2.u: What did you mean, Mr. Faulkner, in—I'm not quite sure how you intended this to be pronounced—I know the word, but this particular spelling of it. Wash says, "if you was A-R-A other man." "Ary other man. Or "ara."
That's right, "ara."
"Ara."
"Ara" or "nara."
Mmhmm.
"Ara." I remember in Alabama, where I lived sort of back in the hills myself, and it was "ary" back there, rather than "ara." Funny—
"Ary."
"Ary." U-huh.
And "nary."
"Nary."
You know that may be an example of of over-correction, just like in the mountains when the name Andy becomes "Anda" sometimes, and Naomi becomes "Naoma."
Or it may be—it may be the—the mountain speech coming down into Northern Alabama there.
Might be.

div2.head: Awry and Ory
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, how do you pronounce these words: "A-W-R-Y haired" and "A-W-R-Y feathered."
Awry.
Awry.
That's what I was trying to spell.
I see. Have you ever heard the pronunciation "ory" haired?
Not in Mississippi—
"Ory" feathered"?
Is that at all similar to "ory eyed"? Or does that refer to another condition or pronunciation.
I think it is. I think it is.
Very likely is, but I never heard "ory" applied to anything except "eye."
Mmmhmm. That's the only usage I know.

div2.head: Dog v Dawg
div2.u: I want to ask Mr. Faulkner—ask you Mr. Faulkner why once you spell the word dog D-A-W-G for Wash. It seems to me that I don't approve of that spelling. That doesn't really differentiate Wash from any of the other characters. Wouldn't they all say "dawg"? Don't you say "dawg"? Doesn't everybody in Mississippi say "dawg."

Yes, the reason for that is that someone has said southerners don't read books; they write books. And I think that when the southerner writes deliberately spelled dialect, he is writing not for the man that calls "dog" "dawg," but for the man that calls "dog" "dog."

But "dawg"—"dawg" is very general all over the country. Of course in some parts of the Midwest people do say "dog." But in New England and the South, and a large part of the rest of the country D-O-G is "dawg"
Yes, but these people would speak with a—even more flatness than that. It would be "Dawg."
Stretched out.
Yes.

div2.head: Hit for It
div2.u: Well another—another point I'd like to ask you about. In the use of "hit" which I'm familiar with in Georgia. It's an old form that's survived. But it seems to me, at least in Georgia, the distinction is this. In an unstressed, where the—where the syllable would not be accented—for instance, you could hardly say—if you wanted to say "Move it over thar," you—it would be hard say "move hit over thar." But if you said, "Hit don't make no difference"—or—when it's stressed, it would be "hit." But I notice you use it rather indiscriminately whether it would be in a stress position or not in a stress position. I think—I think you were careless in that regard.
Perhaps so, but I think I have heard it used—sometimes the same man will say "move hit yonder" or "move it yonder."
And "make it now" and "make hit now."
That's right, the same—
More deliberation.
Well, I don't know. It's—he probably is not aware himself. At one time he puts an and the next time he drops it.
I should think his—the speed with which he spoke or the emotion—
Yes, has a lot to do with it.
That might even determine which spelling—
For instance, here's one. Wash says, "You make hit right," and you spell it H-I-T, which—but again, he says, "Hit don't need no ticket."

div2.head: Fragment
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, one thing that I'd like to get in I've wondered how you do it. Just how you go about it. I see some every now again, some of these words that I think are—are brilliant. Luster, I remember, in the end of The Sound and the Fury, says—

div2.head: Fragment
div2.u: in our memory I should think.
Do you ever create these things?
Probably.
He doesn't mean to, though.
No, I don't deliberately, but I—probably I have corrupted words on my own ticket.
To get a good result.

div2.head: Close
div2.u: We've enjoyed being with you for the past fifteen minutes for this chat. There is much more on the subject that we could say, but our time has run out on us again. However, we cordially invite you to be in our listening audience next week at this same time, when Mr. Faulkner will again be in our—will be our special guest. Joining us around the table today were Mr. Ed Stephenson, Mr. Joseph Blotner, and Mr. Robert Davis. Our special guest for this program was Mr. William Faulkner. This is Atcheson Hench thanking you for joining our discussion today and inviting you to listen again next week at this time for another chat on some aspect of the language we speak.

div2.head: Break, 1
div2.u: Have you been waiting all that time to cough, Mr. Gwynn?
Now's the time for Mr. Hench to get up and do this again.

div2.head: Break, 2
div2.u: You may stretch your muscles just a moment just while we switch tapes and then we'll continue again as though we never stopped.
Well wasn't it brilliant?
That worked very well.
You were great, Hench.

div2.head: Elefunk
div2.u: Oh dear. You know I—you speaking about "elefunk". I think that's one of those rebuildings to suit what the man probably thinks it ought to be, like "plathform" instead of "platform." Though what "funk"—"elefunk" would be I wouldn't have any idea. But he's got some notion in there.

div2.head: Jaybirds and Hell
div2.u: There's something I've wondered about, and I don't guess we can ask it on this program, so I'll just ask it now. I remember Luster says—he chunks some rocks at some jaybirds, and he says, "Git on back to hell, whar you belong at. 'Taint Monday yit." I wondered what that superstition—I never heard that superstition—
The superstition is that on Friday the jaybirds all go to hell; they don't come back till Monday.
around from that Monday until the next Friday.
Quite often you never hear a jaybird over the weekend, and the superstition is they've gone to hell.
That's probably what they've done.
Sometimes that is where they should go—

div2.head: No more despair
div2.u: Gee, there was one that I wanted to ask about. In "Spotted Horses," when Armstid's wife tells how badly off they are and says that "He aint no more despair than to spend four dollars for a horse." I know what she means, but I've just never heard those words put together that way before.
I'm familiar with that.
Are you?
It means he has no more shame, no more consideration, for our trouble.

div2.head: Technical Terms
div2.u: I'm glad you didn't use any—any technical terms on us, Steve, like post-vocalic "r." Stuff like that it was the wrong thing to do.
I slipped up and did that one time. It was the first program we did then I realized that was the wrong thing to do —
You might just as well use Esperanto.
I won't talk about this vowel then.
Good.

div2.head: Starting Program Two
div2.u: Okay? You gentleman ready for—?
Do you want to reset the clock?
I think it does, and that every now and then helps me if I think of it.

div2.head: Swurge for Surge
div2.u: Did you ever hear of "swurge" for "surge?"
No, that was another one I marked in "Spotted Horses." And you didn't invent that either. I thought maybe you invented that. It's a wonderful term, I think. It conveys the idea beautifully, but—
I think I've heard that "w" in certain places. I can't pull one out of my head right now. But I think in the mountains up here, in the Blue Ridge, I've heard a "w" that gets—
It could be. I could see how it happens. It could be the reverse of the loss of the "w" in "sword." "Sward."

div2.head: Opening Program Two
div2.u: Today as our special guest again we have with us the American novelist Mr. William Faulkner, author-in-residence at the University of Virginia this semester. We are indeed fortunate, as we were last week, to have him with us. Also around our table today are our special—are our regular panel members Mr. Edward Stephenson and Mr. Robert Davis. And as another panel member today, we have Mr. Joseph Blotner.

div2.head: Hogfish
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, following up what we said last week, I should like to ask you about the meanings of one or two words. By the way, is there a fish in Mississippi called a "hog"?
No.
Then I misunderstood a line. Somewhere I thought you called a fish a hog. Maybe—there's no hogfish?
No, I think somebody said the catfish the little boy had was as bloody as a hog. It's as full of blood as a hog.
Oh, I see.

div2.head: Frailed
div2.u: What about the word "frailed"? He "frailed him time and time." What's that mean?
To whip, thrash.
It's a variant of flail, isn't it? Yes, I—I know that. It's a variant of flail.
—but they say "frail."
You use that, Mr. Davis?
No, sir, I never heard that—I don't think. Not frail.
Oh, you're too much of a city boy.
I guess so.

div2.head: Dust-dark and Dust-dawn
div2.u: What about these two that are—that always have interested me: "dust-dark" and "dust-dawn." The time of day which is "dust-dark" and "dust-dawn."
Twilight.
What does "dust" mean there?
It's "dusk" really.
Dusk.
But they say "dust." That is, they say "dus-dark" and "dus-dawn." They don't say "dusk-dark" and "dusk-dawn."
If you all would let me be technical I'd say that's assimilation to the following "d." You see—
Of course.
Dusky dark? Have you ever, Mr. Stephenson, heard "dusk-dawn," "dusk-dark"?
No, I don't know that.
But I've heard "dust" for dusk. For the time of day, it's just "dust."

div2.head: Kain't and Class
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, you have—to come back to the story "Wash" again, which I read quite recently—you have Wash say "kain't," but you don't represent the colonel as saying that. Don't you think he would have said "kaint" too?
That was to make a distinction between their social position.
It's—it's really a sort of faking in a way. I mean I don't mean to be nitpicking but—
Well, don't you think really the—the colonel himself would have been conscious of such things as pronunciation and perhaps would have stressed it where Colonel Sartoris might not have?

I doubt that. It was Wash's flat drawl. The colonel would have said "kaint"; Wash would have said "kayint." And the only way I know to do that is to spell it slightly different. Wash has a flatter voice than the plantation owner—and the master. Though they would use the same—

div2.head: Holler
div2.u: In that same story, Millie says to Wash, "You'll have to holler—you'll have to holler louder than that." "Holler," I suppose. H-O-L-L-E-R, you spelled it. That comes back to the question we asked last week about what would you do with "winder" if you wanted to have one of the poor white trash—
Well—
It's a problem, isn't it. Because now if this were one of the upper class characters, H-O-L-L-E-R would represent "holla," But knowing that it's Wash's daughter it's going to be "holler."
That's right.
So we have to know something about the background.

div2.head: Figures of Speech
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, do you—you have—must have an astonishingly retentive memory for figures of speech. I noticed you spoke of a coffin "as neat as a sewing basket." And the talk of some women as kind of like "bees murmuring in a water bucket." Do you—are these phrases that are proverbial in your talk—in the talk of people in Mississippi, or do you make these up, or—or what? They're delightful phrases.

Those, I imagine, the circumstances of the story invent themselves, suggest to me. I've never heard them as— as analogies. Simply the circumstances of the story—or the desire to describe that the best I can in comprehensible phrases or figures of speech.

div2.head: Sources of Figures
div2.u: Do you have any idea which kinds of things you like most to use figures of speech—make figures of speech out of. Flowers or fish or horses or dogs or trees or just—or don't you worry and care less?
I would say that the—the—the instant I am involved with does the commanding in that.

I think one of the most unusual kinds of figures of speech that I've noticed—when certain of your characters—certain of your more perceptive characters like Benjy in The Sound and the fury and Darl in As I Lay Dying—their sense of smell seems to be very acute. I know Darl says—when it's getting ready to rain he says it smells like sulfur. Well, even Quentin in The Sound and the Fury remembers the smell of the honeysuckle and so forth. I—I think that's particulary good and it's rather unusual, I think. Because usually that's one of the senses—one of the five that's left out so often in writing. It gives that added touch of realism to it.

div2.head: Christmas Masts
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, may I ask you if I—if there's something here in Mississippi folklore that I missed, not having grown up in Mississippi. Cora says, "His face looked like one of these here Christmas masts that had been—that had done been buried a while and then dug up." What is a Christmas "mast"?
Oh, the toy mask, the comic faces that children buy in the—in the stores for Halloween and—and Christmas time.
And "mast" is really for "mask"?
Mask, yes.
Just like "dusty" for "dusk."
Yes, that's right.

div2.head: Bot as Misprint
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, in "The Bear," here's a word I don't know. I wonder if you can tell me what it means. The word is B-O-T: "The old game crossing over which he'd trailed bucks wounded and not wounded and more than once seen them anything but wounded bot out of the woods and up and across the embankment—" What's that word B-O-T mean? It looks like a verb having to do with rapid motion or something of the sort.
I would have to see it.
Maybe it's a misprint?
It is a misprint, yes. There's no such word as that. If it's not a misprint for "but" then—
"But out of the woods" would make sense. Or could it be "hot out of the woods"?
That's a good point.
Wherever
"Hot."
"Hot out of the woods." I see.
Yes, I remember. It was hot.
"Hot out of the woods." That's a misprint.
Running at top speed. Yes, "hot out of the woods."

div2.head: Chapping
div2.u: Do all—do many people use the word "chapping" for having children. Somebody said, "We ain't nigh done chapping yet."

That's quite colloquial. You hear that only in the remote hill country. People that—that have no—where there are no Negroes and their speech is not corrupted by—by Negro inflections and the Negro usage of words. That came from Scotland.

div2.head: Lawed
div2.u: Is "lawed"—would you say of—the same thing of "lawed." "He should be lawed for treating her so." In other words arrested or something.
That's not all—making a verb out of a noun.
You did that yourself?
No. I've heard that.
Oh, I see.
That's—I imagine that that's in Georgia and Alabama, too.

div2.head: Tongued
div2.u: What does this mean, Mr. Faulkner? Let's see, "They all piled over the crest of the hill just in time to see Tomey's Turl a way out across the flat almost to the woods and the dogs streaking down the hill and out onto the flat. They just tongued once and when they came boiling up around Tomey's Turl they looked like they were going to jump up and lick him in the face."
Another verb made from a noun. They "gave tongue" once.
You've never hunted.
No, I'm not a hunter.
Well, Mr. Faulkner is. He's heard the sound of dogs.
That means they were—they were on game. They bayed once, then they recognized Tomey's Turl, a friend, so they quit.
I see.
They just caught up with him to lick his hand, to run along with him.

div2.head: A Tie-up
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, what is a tie-up in a barn?
That's anything you tie cattle to. It's near a rack for feeding.
Oh, I see. A rack or a bar.
A hitch or a lead is snapped into the halter—tied to a bar.

div2.head: Soopled
div2.u: And another place, Mr. Faulkner, "Black John came out of the trees, driving, soopled out flat and level as a hawk." Is that a verb made from the adjective "supple"?
Yes, they pronounce "supple," "soople."
I've heard the pronunciation of the adjective as "soople." This is a verb in the past tense, "soopled."
Yes, that's right. To—to "soople" is to do something rapid and limber.

div2.head: Regional Dialects Q
div2.u: Mr. Faulkner, some days ago I remember your saying that you thought you could move, say, to a Maine village, a fishing village or a lumbering village, and it wouldn't be long before you would be writing about people there. Yet I remember yesterday you said that it was the inflection, the sound of the words and the dialect that was very much a part of the people that you write about. Don't you think that, though you could see stories quickly in the lives of this imagined Maine group of people, it would take you a long time to get on to their talk, their pronunciation, and so forth?
